poem:
**Second-Class Delivery**

Alternate streets  
where whispers  
thread through fading  
blue veins—  
paused,  
only to stir again  
in absent rhythm.

Yet Saturday  
awaits silence,  
unspoken letters  
nested in stillness.  
First-class chatter  
claims its space—  
a different pace,  
but always,  
the heart listens.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Royal Mail should cut second-class delivery days, says regulator Ofcom Royal Mail is set to be allowed to deliver second-class letters only on alternate weekdays and not on Saturdays under proposals to shake-up postal service rules announced the industry regulator. Ofcom said cutting second class letters to every other week day, but still within three working days of collection and with a price cap, while maintaining first-class letters six days a week, would still meet". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
